description:
Lodderomyces beijingensis is a species of yeast that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Beijing, China. It belongs to the phylum Ascomycota, the class Saccharomycetes, and the order Saccharomycetales.

Lodderomyces beijingensis is a unicellular, asexual, and heterotrophic organism. It is capable of reproducing through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. The cells are typically oval or round in shape and measure approximately 3-6 micrometers in diameter.

Genetically, Lodderomyces beijingensis is closely related to other members of the genus Lodderomyces, which are known to be involved in various fermentation processes and have potential applications in biotechnology. The species has been studied for its ability to produce certain metabolites and enzymes that may be of interest in industrial or medical applications.

While the specific ecological role and niche of Lodderomyces beijingensis in its natural environment are not fully understood, its isolation from soil samples suggests that it may play a role in nutrient cycling or other soil-based processes.
